mods.note: This lithograph is from theartist's "New Orleans Series". It is drawn with a lithographic pencil and using a brush with lithographic ink. One may note that the entire background is ink painted onto the stone by brush. The suggestion for the face in the print came from an experience in New Orleans. Ms. Durieux had x-rays made while in New Orleans by a young x-ray technician. The technician was a Jew who seemed to have one of the saddest faces seen by the artist. As it was the time of Jewish persecution in Germany, the artist related his saddened features of those misfortunate Jews in Europe. She used his face to represent the exiled Jew at this time of world trouble. The black background surrounds the face and adds to the feeling of dark sadness of the work. The background, related Ms. Durieux, is again a technical "device" used by the artist. The black area allows the viewer to become involved in the composition allowing the viewer's eye to create an outline for the face and head of the youth. "A technical device is used by the artist for the viewer's sake... a technical device belongs to the artist, not the viewer."
